conversation.message: Hello Company_A—I'm Seeker_B and I’m applying for your open role. I’m highly motivated to join Company_A as my top choice and believe I can contribute immediately with strong execution, collaboration, and ownership. If selected, I’m ready to commit and start promptly. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: I should start by applying to my top choice, Company_A. Although Company_A ranks me 4th, early application gives me a chance before they lock in a higher-priority candidate. If rejected, I can pivot next round to Company_B where I am ranked 2nd and have strong acceptance odds. Message will be concise, signal fit, and ask for consideration for their single opening.

conversation.message: Hi Seeker_B—thank you for applying and for your strong interest in Company_A. After reviewing our current candidate pool for this round, we won’t be moving forward with your application at this time. We appreciate your time and wish you the best in your search.
conversation.thought: Company_A has quota 1 and received [APPLY] from Seeker_B and Seeker_E in round 1. On Company_A’s true priority list, Seeker_E is ranked #1 while Seeker_B is ranked #4. Since Seeker_E is available and has applied, accepting Seeker_B now would block a higher-priority match. Therefore, reject Seeker_B to preserve capacity for Seeker_E. Also, Seeker_B ranks Company_A as #1, but Company_A’s objective is to maximize its own priority match within quota, so it should prioritize Seeker_E.

conversation.message: Hello Company_A — I’m Seeker_E. I’m very interested in joining and believe I’d be a strong fit. Company_A ranks me 1st, and it is my 3rd choice, making it a strong, high-probability match. Securing Company_A now avoids being left with a low-ranked option later.

conversation.message: Hi Seeker_E—thank you for applying to Company_A. We’re excited about your interest and strong fit. We’d like to move forward and extend you an offer for the role. [ACCEPT]

Accepting Seeker_E immediately secures our top choice and avoids the risk of losing them to other companies (Seeker_E prefers Company_C and Company_D over us). Seeker_B also applied but is ranked lower (4th) on our list and was previously rejected; accepting Seeker_E dominates any alternative and fills our single slot optimally.

Seeker_C and Seeker_D are both higher on our list than Seeker_A, so we should not accept Seeker_A given current alternatives and the possibility of better future applicants.
